segments.text: You were relating your view of the people of Vietnam.
How do you feel about the Army of South Vietnam, the ARVN?
Not very well.
They weren't worth the powder to kill them all with.
Some elitist type units, such as the ARVN Rangers, ARVN Special Forces, ARVN SEALs, we had our counterparts in the ARVN all the way along, were fairly good.
They were
really hardcore trained in the warrior spirit.
You could have pointed them in any direction.
The enemy wouldn't have mattered.
Just go do, kill, destroy, and they would have done it.
In that sense, they were okay, but that's not what wins a war for a nation.
It's the support of the nation, the people behind it, and so on, such as we had in World War II.
It was a common enemy to the whole world.
And everyone pulled together
more or less, to win that war.
There were a lot of war protestors then.
The Civil War, the American Revolutionary War.
There was always somebody protesting war.
That's been going on for thousands of years, thousands of generations.
But in World War II, there was a common goal.
In Vietnam, there wasn't.
The people of Vietnam did not have a common goal, other than they just wanted to be left alone, grow their rice, raise their kids so the kids could grow their rice and raise more kids.
Very simple people.
Didn't require a whole lot.
Very superstitious people.
And they were not ambitious at all.
They were bellicose.
Life meant nothing to them.
But to look at them at the time, they weren't helping me help them.
And that's all I saw.
and I had absolutely no use for them.
That developed over a period of time.
Like I said, I went in there trying not to be the ugly American, having lived in several foreign countries and traveled Europe and so on and so forth, and it got along quite well.
I learned to speak German fairly fluently in the villages and in the towns, not in the classroom.
Gained respect and many friends in Germany.
Didn't go to the GI hangout.
That's just the way my thought pattern is.
And I tried the same thing in Vietnam.
It didn't work.
It did not work at all.
All they wanted was everything I had.
The Montagnards of Vietnam I still to this day hold in high esteem.
They're the mountain people.
That's what Montagnard means.
They took it on the chin, even from the Vietnamese.
The Vietnamese hated it.
Everybody hated it.
They were independent mountain people.
They lived their own lives.
They were ferocious warriors, too.
One of the most ferocious I ever met was a 13-year-old kid.
And he was the platoon leader of a mercenary force, or might force for a special forces operation.
And that's fixing to get off into a war story, and I don't tell war stories.
But he was a ferocious fighter.
And I gave his body back to his grandfather, brought it in on my ship.
That's the kind of people they were.
They were, of course, primitive, extremely superstitious.
Case in point, I was carrying a med cap team into a Montagnard village just to help them out medicine-wise, inoculate the kids and stuff like that, and try and help them out wherever they could.
And that morning, a pair of twins had been born.
And they were going through the ceremony of burying these twins alive because they were twins.
And that was an evil omen.
Now, that's how superstitious and printed they were.
We bought the twins for a hunting knife and some beads.
They didn't know what money was, but that had no value to them.
They could use a knife.
Oh, yeah, I gave them some bullets, too, for an AK-47 they had.
And some shotgun shells.
And that's what we bought those twins with.
We turned them over to some missionaries.
Whatever happened with that, I don't know.
But the Montagnards, I liked those people.
They knew what they wanted.
They knew where they stood.
They were willing to die for it.
Now, that I respect, but I'm a warrior.
And that's the way I've trained myself to be all my life.
Even when I was a little kid, that's what I wanted to be.
So that holds the highest esteem for me.
At that time, in particular, the Vietnamese population in general weren't that way.
The peasants wanted to be left alone.
They didn't want anything to do with anybody.
The European influenced part of the populace was trying to grab anything they could get.
The old
How the words of that song go, the old, old story, a play for power and glory, something like that.
That's what they were after.
It's biblical.
And it was their downfall.
They destroyed themselves.
But they killed a lot of my friends in the process.
And that part I did not like.
Could you let your view of the VC or the VidCon, you know,
What you felt they were fighting for?
They were fighting for an idea.
They had an idea.
As I mentioned earlier, the communists simply told those people and demonstrated to them the truth about their own government, how corrupt it was, and that we were adding to that corruption.
We were no better than what they had.
This wasn't hard to demonstrate.

their hard part was to convince the populace that they were the answer rather than us and they did this through some pretty vicious means as far as fighting us yeah it was pretty dirty and we hated them we'd kill them on sight it was they were fair game but i really had to hand it to them the vc mortarmen were the best i ever saw that couple of guys on the mortar you know untrained unskilled but yet trained and skilled
farmers by day, mortarmen by night.
They could put ten rounds in the air, move the tube, and start ten more before the first one hit the ground.
And be accurate.
They were really good.
But they had an idea that they wanted to free their country from the yoke of colonialism.
And we hear it referred to as imperialism.
That's really not.
Everything's imperialistic.
But it was the colonialism that had
oppressed them for so many, many, many years.
And they had this idea, much like what we had in the late 1700s, of throwing off a colonial yoke.
And they believed in it, just like our forefathers believed in it.
And our forefathers were the ragtag bunch of ill-fed, ill-equipped, and untrained people defeated the British Empire.
beat them into submission until they could not afford to wage war anymore.
The VC did exactly the same thing to us.
The saddest part of all this is we haven't learned the lesson from it.
I recognize it for what it is now, but then I did not.
But I did respect the true VC soldier.
And the NBA sold.
I respected my enemy.
I saw him do a job on us too many times not to.
We had them overpowered.
We were smarter and better equipped, and we could have outlasted them had we had a will to win.
We didn't.
They did.
They have the country.
We don't.
They have a lot of the stuff we left behind.
We don't.
They're not as prosperous as they said they were going to be.
In fact, it's a disaster.
But they got it.
And they don't.
I honestly believe that what those people needed was what they got.
That's what they understand.
Did that answer your question?
We'll shift gears here a bit and talk about politics in the United States.
When you served in Vietnam, you served under both President Johnson and Nixon.
What do you think of their administrations, their effects on the world, their effects on you?
Johnson inherited the Vietnam War from Kennedy.
And from what I understand now, Kennedy wanted to bail out of it, but didn't know how to do it gracefully.
And then he got assassinated, and Johnson inherited the thing.
He made the mistake of believing Wes Moreland.
He didn't know what to do.
And whatever he did was wrong.
Any way he turned was wrong.
I got real upset and angry with him when he stopped the bombing along Ho Chi Minh Trail because I was directly at the brunt of that stuff and it directly affected me.
And we started getting plastered real good because they started getting resupplied real good.
Under Nixon, everything was winding down.
While I was there on my second tour, we turned over the big 9th Infantry Division facility at Dong Tam to the Vietnamese.
This is going to be another nail in their integrity coffin.
I flew in there one day on the way to Saigon.
while they were having this ceremony of turning the place over.
They directed us way out and around and had to come in an oddball way so that we wouldn't disturb them.
And we saw it from the air and remarked about it and made snide remarks and yelled and screamed and hollered at them.
Of course, they couldn't hear us.
But they had a real nice air facility there.
Real nice revetments with solid steel planking, steel posts in the ground, dirt three foot thick in it, you know, that was kind of protected from shrapnel and stuff like that.
And a real nice refueling facility, a nice shed there for the operators to get in and out of elements.
Just a real nice facility.
And we came back through late that afternoon.
This was fairly early in the morning, about, well, I guess it was late in the morning, about 9 o'clock, 10 o'clock, something like that.
It was fairly late.
We'd been going through daylight.
But we came back late that afternoon and stopped for fuel again.
The place was stripped bare.
There wasn't a piece of metal in sight.
While they were turning the facility over to the Vietnamese, the soldiers and civilians were out there stripping it of anything of value.
Same thing happened with the Navy facility in Bintui.

They were down the street having a ceremony, turning it over to them, and the guys were down the other end of the street taking the urinals and toilets out of the building and taking them home so they could sell it.
Some of them didn't even have a place to hook it up.
They were just taking it.
That led to that, but I'm getting off the subject here.
Nixon, pretty much in his era, was winding things down, which I kind of appreciate.
I wish he had just said, it's over, finished, get on the truck, let's go home.
Well, he took too long in doing it and it cost more lives, but finally he declared victory and we left, which is about the only way we could have done it, really.
And we all laughed about it then.
We were all sarcastic and cynical about it.
But in retrospect, that's the only thing he could have done.
Just jumped up and said, we win, and left.
I just wish he'd have done it sooner.
Johnson I had no use for.
Nixon either.
We got less for Johnson.
He could have stopped things, and he didn't.
He made it worse.
He could have bailed out, but he didn't.
And he knew he could have.
So much for politics.
Politics and soldiers make strange bedfellows, some of us said.
You had said something about Westmoreland.
How did you see his methods, the strategy that he had followed?
Westmoreland did not believe that fraggings were going on.
He would not accept the fact that drugs were rampant after 69 and 70 through there.
They were rampant throughout the military in Southeast Asia, not just the Army.
He wouldn't accept it.
A year ago, I listened to Westmoreland give a speech in Houston at the gathering of Vietnam veterans at the Welcome Home Parade they had.
I led that parade, by the way.
Didn't know it when it happened, but as it turned out, when we got to the other end, I said, where's everybody at?
And some guy said, hey, they're all behind us.
We're in front.
I said, ain't that something?
And it was all helicopter pilots.
And we led the way, and I carried the banner the whole three miles.
God, did my feet hurt.
But I listened to him give a speech that afternoon against the movie Platoon, which he admitted at the time he hadn't even seen it.
And he wanted all of us to write our congressmen and anybody else of any import to have the thing done away with.
Not to show it.
Don't go see it.
That's censorship.
Of the worst kind.
He thought that it was all a bunch of hooey.
Well, I know better.
I did see the movie.
I have a tape of the movie.
I've studied the movie.
It crammed a lot into a little bit of time, but it made more sense than the other idiotic things that they put out.
I'm not even talking about Rambo.
I don't even mention that.
That's pure bull.
But Apocalypse Now was an abstract thing, way out on the edges of believability.
But the things that occurred in Platoon did happen.
People smoked dope.
People shot their leaders in the back.
Leaders shot their people.
Every kind of human emotion that you can think of comes out in stress situations like combat, particularly in combat, particularly where you've got a gun and people expect you to kill something.
That happens.
When you turn kids loose like that without good guidance and direction, they take so much and they just crack.
And they just start killing anything in sight.
When we were kids, we'd throw rocks at things.
Their rock was an M-16.
So these things did happen.
Westmoreland refused to accept it.
He didn't believe it and wanted the rest of us not to believe it.
The drug problem became rampant because he wouldn't address it.
He was telling the Congress and the President that this was this way and that was that way, and it wasn't that way at all.
He blew it on Tet, 68.
They caught us with our pants down, plain and simple.
We came back and did something about it, but we could have stopped it long before it ever started, months before it ever started, if he'd have only listened to these intelligence people.
They were telling him that the thing was going to happen.
And he wouldn't accept it.
He was too much of the old school, too much West Point.
Way too much West Point.
You were saying about Westmoreland and his strategies.
I mean, how do you feel about the other officers that you were under?
Not very much.
On the subject of shooting the leaders, I came very close to it myself.
A particular operation that happened in the Docto area, Firebase 19.
I watched a lot of people, including my roommate in flight school, die that day.
I watched the bullets hit his body.
I watched him rip open his fuel tank.
He'd been shot down in the LZ.
He was a medevac pilot.
He was going in trying to rescue people.
He got shot down, and then he got wounded getting out of the aircraft.
And it was the only cover there, so they stayed right there.
And I was coming in to get him until the ship blew up in front of me.
And I watched the burning fuel spew out over him, and I watched it fry him.
All because this one battalion commander advertised for three days exactly where we were going to land.
And he put ordnance artillery everywhere but that place.
It was the only safe place for the NVA to be.
And they were there when we got there.
And they hurt us real bad.
Hurt us bad.
I come close to killing that battalion commander.
I believe it's, if I remember correctly,
seven-and-a-half-pound trigger pull on a standard issue .45 automatic.
I had about three ounces to go.
And my crew chief, a very big strapping kid from Pennsylvania, took the gun away from me, picked me up off the ground, and carried me away.
Somebody else carried that colonel away.
He couldn't walk.
I'd already done the job on him.
They got him out of country that day because I wasn't the only one to complain.
That whole battalion was ready to kill him.
for what was left of them, most of them were dead.
So some of their operations they planned were just asinine.
They were elaborate wallboard drawings with elaborate time schedules and artillery schedules and things like this that were going to get somebody killed if they were so much as 10 seconds off.
I was air mission commander one day on a particular one of these forces.
And I canceled the entire mission because of the elaboracy of the thing.
And in the briefing, when it got around to me, this battalion commander said, who's the air mission commander?
And I stuck my hand up.
I had 13 ships to help me make this assault with.
Unlucky number, but we liked it that way.
It was my call sign was 13.
Gladiator 1-3.
He asked me what I thought about it.
I said, I think your plan stinks, and I'm not going to use my aircraft to do it.
You're going to get my people killed.
He exploded, ordered me off the field.
We left.
My battalion commander came in, told him he was crazy.
If he'd tell me where he wanted his troops picked up and where he wanted them put, we would do that.
But we weren't going to play his stupid, silly games.
So my battalion commander was pretty sharp.
He backed me up.
And we didn't do it.
And the mission was canceled.
And it would have gotten
Probably half of us wiped out because it was so elaborate no one could keep the schedule.
It was like 10 second differences.
I'm going to shut the artillery off and 10 seconds later we're going to land.
They came up with all kinds of cockamamie things like that.
Their whole thinking about this was a conventional warfare.
That if we could catch the VC in the open and take him on head to head, we could defeat him.
That's true, we could.
When I say the VC, I really mean the NVA, because that's who we're up against.
They wouldn't meet us head-to-head like that.
We'd already heard them too many times for them to meet us head-on, head-to-head.
They'd catch us where they could and wear us down, just wear us down, constantly working at us, like dripping water on a stone.
Sooner or later, it's going to be all of it.
But our commanders wanted to fight a conventional war in an unconventional situation and use all their toys, like the helicopters,
the B-52s out of Guam, all this stuff, and believe that because of all this might, we were invincible.
I think Gideon showed the Amalekites that they weren't.
I believe he had 300, and they had 10,000 or something like that.
So might is not always right, but our commanders believed that it was.
And they were foolish.
And they expected us to be fools too.
You said too much West Point.
Mm-hmm.
You think it got too technological to buy the paper.
Buy the paper.
Too much West Point.
The Klan.
They're still fighting Napoleon's battles.
The guy I like to lead me is
A fella that used to be a loan officer down at the bank got something to live for.
He wants to get this damn thing over with and go home.
And the best way to get it over with is to kick their butt until they can't be kicked anymore, and then we win.
Pick up the marbles and go.
I like those kind of people.
They're level-headed.
They've got a little savvy about what's right and what's wrong, not about what gets them ticket punched and their career advanced.
Ticket punching was the order of the day in Vietnam for career senior officers.
Captains were a dime a dozen.
I was offered direct to first lieutenant several times, turned it down.
If I'd have taken it one year later, I'd have been a captain.
The congressional cap on the amount of captains we could have in the Army was lifted completely.
There was no limit.
They wanted captains to take the heat for something.
captain is exactly the right level.
He's a company commander.
We're not going to risk our West Point lieutenant colonel or major when we can get some OCS captain or direct commission guy in there that was a lone officer in the bank back home.
Stuff like this or just was in the wrong place at the wrong time and got made a captain.
Those are the guys I'll follow.
Those are the guys I'd love to lead.
That's most of what I have, which is plain GI Joe
Nothing fancy.
They just wanted to get over with it and go home.
You said G.I.
Joe's.
How much of a difference do you think there were between the professional soldiers like yourself and the selective service?
The draftees?
The best soldiers I ever met.
They kept us old pros in line.
The ones I always had the most trouble with,
where the kids that enlisted asked for it and didn't really realize what they were getting into and weren't mature enough to accept what they had stumbled into.
The draftee, he was there to do his time, get it over with, and go home.
As far as that goes in Vietnam, once it got to a point, everybody was the same.
Of course, the professional hardcore like myself
We just kept on keeping on.
And it boiled down to just basic leadership.
Could you get along with people?
Could you get them to do what you wanted them to do?
Rank and authority only went so far.
It was just a hand grenade away from not having any existence at all.
So it was real obvious to me, having come up through the ranks, a Mustang, and having been a sergeant,
first-line leader and things like that, that you don't just tell people what to do.
That's not leadership.
You've got to work with them.
You've got to be there with them.
You've got to take the same risks, sleep in the same mud, eat the same rotten grub, or don't eat it.
And I never ate unless my crew was fed first.
Never.
And out of that, I got their loyalty
And there were times when I asked them to do things that were literally impossible, but they did it.
And they always came through for me.
And I brought them all home.
The spectrum of the war just totally covered, affected the United States so much.
you know, the anti-war protests and stuff.
And my next, you know, line of questions were going to cover the media involvement in it, and what you saw their effect was.
Far away.
I mean, what overall do you think the, how did the media affect the war?
Very much so.
When you say the media, that's the plural.
Newspapers, television, radio, the whole nine yards.
For the first time in the history of the world, you had a war a world away in your living room, literally hours after it occurred, on television, in living color.
And uncensored.
They could say and do anything they wanted to do.
It'd be incredible to think about it right now with satellite capability that we didn't have then.
My God, you could be right in the middle of a battle as it is occurring.
This is a live report from the front.
We're going to John Jones up there, and he's getting shot at even as we speak.
We could do that now.
It was almost that then.
And every night it was the same thing.
One of the things that turned most of us military against the media, the professional corps, was the fact that they weren't on our side.
What we didn't realize was why they weren't on our side.
We didn't know.
We did not have a plan to win.
They knew it.
And they took incidents like the police chief in Saigon summarily executing a guy on the street and I'm not going to judge one way or the other.
Stuff happens and it happens fast.
But they took things like that and they hit people with it.
I objected greatly to their reports of Tet 68.
They were reporting literally within hours of occurrence getting it on some sort of a
feedback to the states that we were losing the war.
In fact, we were winning.

One of the things that they failed to mention after they had said all the horrible, ugly things we'd done and all the people we'd killed in the Waifu Bay area, they seemed to have neglected to remember that the NVA and the VC infrastructure that came in there executed 5,000 to 8,000 people in a period of about a week or so.
or a month, I don't know exactly how long ago.
I've got the figures in one of my references.
But executed these people because they were teachers, lawyers, they were leaders in the community and things like that.
Literally executed them and buried them in a mass grave.
They never really brought all that out.
They were just after our own people.
That disturbed us greatly.
I had some personal dealings with...
television crew and reporters.
And their arrogance was beyond mine.
And that was pretty bad.
I was pretty arrogant.
I was a shit-hot jet-jumper.
And I couldn't be killed.
Well, I earned mine.
They just did theirs.
I didn't like them at all.
I still don't like the way they portray things, but through them I learned a lot of the truths of what really went on.
what was going on behind the scenes in the Congress, in the executive branch, the things that affected me out there at Contum Army Airfield.
But I still don't like the way they did it.
They tend to blow things out of proportion.
And they put it in everybody's living room, and they helped cut us down.
I don't think they really knew they were doing it, though.
You get right down to it.
It borders on aiding and abetting the enemy, but I don't think they knew they were doing it.
They didn't mean to, and I believe they did that for a second.
But they could have done a better job for the grunt.
Rather than trying to stop the war strategically, they could have helped in supporting our efforts.
And we know now how important that was to the North Vietnamese government.
was they knew that we did not have the popular support, therefore they continued to press the point.

Just like the neighborhood bully, if he knows you're not going to hit him and fight back, he's going to pick on you even more until he gets the indication that you're going to hurt him bad and that you have the rest of the neighborhood's support.
As long as the neighborhood's not going to stop him, he's going to continue to push everybody around.
But as soon as the neighborhood stands up and says, we're not taking any of this anymore off you, butch, he's going down.
The same rule applies.
They didn't help us.
They did hurt us.
And I did not like them.
And I still don't like them.
You were married throughout this time.
I mean, that must have had...
a devastating effect on your family back home, seeing this on television.
Yes, it did.
I mean, how did you see that?
My children were quite small.
My son, who was the youngest, was born in 1971, just before I went back to my second tour.
My oldest daughter was born before I went back to Germany the second time.
My youngest daughter was born five days before I graduated from flight school.
They're Vietnam veterans, too.
I didn't realize that until just a few years ago.
And to give them the credit for it, they've had to live with the effect of what happened to me and what happened in those days.
My daughters were too young to realize what they were seeing on the news.
I don't think they even watched it, but my wife did.
And I showed you my map on the wall.
That was her map.
And she surmised where I was at.
I wouldn't tell her.
She finally figured it out.
And it was while I was home on that unauthorized R&R back to the States for my daughter's birthday, my unit had been hit pretty bad in a night attack.
And the news just said a helicopter base north of Pleiku.
And when he did, I jerked around in my chair.
And at that moment, my wife knew where it was.
She said, I knew it.
It's a contoon.
Well, I think on it now,

how did she do it i knew what was going on with me i was there and i had a little bit of control over what happened to me i could elect not to go into an area if i wanted to and i was in control of my aircraft and i knew when to zig and zag all she could do was sit and wait for some guy to drive up in front of the house in a uniform
and walk slowly up the walk and knock at the door.
I think about that now, and I think how much stronger she is than I am.
I couldn't have done that.
I couldn't have sat still for it.
I would have gone nuts.
But she did it, day in and day out, for two tours.
And then she put up with what was left over for all these years since then.
And she stayed by me through all of it.
And it got pretty bad for a while.
She talked me out of a divorce three times.
Quite a gal.
Not the most glamorous thing in the world, but her loyalty knows no end.
And I still wonder why she stuck with me.
I'm no prize.
But it did have a great effect on her.
And a lot of all the veterans' families.
I lost my family because of the war.
My own mother called me a baby killer and a murderer.
To this day, I don't know where she's at.
After my father died, she sold everything and left.
Just picked up and took off.
And I haven't seen her since.
Don't even know where she's at.
But they turned against me.
Even my dad didn't want that much to do with me anymore.
The one uncle that was in Europe in World War II, in the infantry, he's the only one that I ever get along with anymore.
And we don't talk about it.
It's just that we know.
And it's enough that we know.
So it devastated the families.
Many families didn't survive it.
And there's a poem out, it's a rather long one, by a guy named Steve Mason.
No.
Steve Mason wrote the book Chicken House.
A fellow named Mason.
And he addresses that, the wall within, the name of the poem.
I can't even begin to quote it.
But some of the things that he points out in this, they go right to the heart of it.
How many long-distance telephone callers were there?
How many
The kids got a good stepdad out of the deal.
Did their Vietnam veteran father not love them?
No.
He loved them too much to stay around and hurt them anymore.
He couldn't stand the pain anymore.
The effect on the families was enormous, incredible.
And those families that did survive, survival of the fittest.
Those families that didn't, it's difficult for me to condemn them anymore.
I used to because I was ignorant and didn't know any better.
But to finally realize what they had to put up with and the enormity of it, I can have a better understanding for it.
I'm extremely fortunate.
My old gal has stuck by me through thick and thin.
And I don't know of any other woman that I know, and I know of a lot of them, that would have done that.
I know of none that can compare to her.
And when I think of heroes, she's mine.
When I think of character and integrity, she's the example.
How do you feel, because you were talking about your uncle before World War II, how do you feel, I mean, the Vietnam War seems...
so different from the rest of them.
It wasn't as popular.
Well, that's the key word.
Popular.
What's popular?
A common goal.
We didn't have a common goal.
I think initially that they were radicals that were just against the government, and that happened to be the event of the day, and they picked up on it.
I don't put anything past the communists.
They'll take advantage of any situation they can, any way they can, especially if they can get somebody else to take the rap for them.
And I've seen it too many times all over the world, every place I've ever been.
They got in there and got it stirred up too.
But here we had this faction that was saying, no, it's wrong.
this is, you know, we're trying to impose our will upon a government.
In fact, we're trying to establish a government outside the government.
And they were right.
Only we couldn't believe something like that was possible in this country.
But it was.
And it was happening.
These young radicals, many of them recognize it, tried to tell the rest of us the truth.
We wouldn't listen because we were too caught up in our old ways.
We had been taught ways for
Had the wisdom of generations before us pounded into us from birth.
You get a job, you settle down, you work hard, you raise your kids, you go to church, you do whatever you want.
And this is the way you do it.
This is the American way.
And that's the way we believe it should be.
The good guys win.
And so on and so forth.
But it wasn't that way.
At all.
And we wouldn't listen.
So we lost the popularity.
There was no common goal.
For us to help that country defeat the communists, no, that was a convenient thing for us to take on the communists, head to head, try out some new ideas and weapon systems and so on.
Had it been for that, the helicopter wouldn't have gotten the development that it realizes today.
It would still be in its infant stages.
So the popularity is what we lack.
There was no Hitler.
There was no Hirohiko.
Ho Chi Minh was an abstract thing.
Like the guy said, it was a dirty, nasty little war, but it was the only one us professionals had to fight, and by God, we were going to fight it.
It was the only one they'd let us fight, and we wanted to fight it.
We're scrappers.
That's why we do this stuff.
So the difference between World War II and Vietnam, look at Korea, the same thing.
It was an unpopular war.

But the convention of the day, people just didn't do that, like what happened in 68 and 67 and 69, the riots and the Chicago 7, the bombings of university ROTC departments and computers and stuff like that.
The convention of the day wouldn't allow things like that, World War II, Korea.
The new age, the age of Aquarius that came into the 60s, the openness, that allowed it to happen.
Everybody wanted to throw off the shackles of the old stoic establishment.
And a lot of us knew that if you did that, it would be chaos.
And it was.
I like to think that something good came out of the whole mess, but I hate to think that nothing did.
But we did not have the popular support of the people.
the VC did.
Now that ought to tell future leaders and future generations something.
You don't have the population behind you.
You're nowhere.
And we were trying to win their hearts and minds by blowing them up.
Do you feel that the
I mean, going back to the question of the media, do you feel that the media was a...
Contributing factor?
Or was a contributing factor to the riots and the anti-war?
They were a contributing factor, and that's all.
Or do you think that it was the other way around?
I think after a certain point during the late 60s, they each began to feed upon each other.
The media saw the riots, showed it, advertised it, populized it, and then the riots took advantage of the media, just like the terrorists of the late 70s and early 80s did.
If they wouldn't get the media coverage, they wouldn't have any reason to do anything because they would not be believing that they were held in such popularity.
all the terrorist activities in the late 70s and early 80s, every one of them said, we want TV coverage.
Well, it began to feed on itself.
Now the media has become the victim of it.
But that's their problem.
Do you think there was any condemnation?
I mean, was the media more radical because of the feelings in the United States?
There's an old adage in...
News reporting is if there's not any news, go make some.
And they're all guilty of that.
And they admit it.
I've heard them admit it dozens of times.
They all know that.
It boils down to the responsibility in reporting.
Where do you go?
How far do you go?
What are you trying to say?
Are you just trying to get better ratings, sell more newspapers, and so on and so forth?
Especially television news reporting, they're after ratings, period, advertising dollars.
That's mercenary, the worst kind of mercenary as far as I'm concerned.
And the more spectacular thing that they can come up with, the better their rating is going to be.
And they have ways of judging and engaging in this that are accurate.
Really accurate.
Accurate enough to sell advertising.
Multi-million dollar packages, which is what they're after.
It's a business.
But it's business creates chaos.
Shifting a bit to the anti-war protests, you were saying, I've kind of picked from what you're saying, that there's mainly like two reasons.
It's said that the 50s were a silent generation, and it seems that the 60s just seem to be tired of this.
Why do you think they were anti-war protests to begin with?
It started out as a legitimate thing.
And from what I see now, looking back on it now, at the time I didn't know all this stuff because I was basically uneducated.
Highly motivated, sincere, but stupid.
Ignorant.
But looking back on it now, the kids coming out of the 50s into the 60s, coming up behind me, they had had all of the
depression, war stories, and stuff like that, that they were going to take and say, hey, this is mine, I'm taking hold of it.
And the whole world opened up before them.
Things changed rapidly.
Attitudes, the whole nine yards.
The Timothy Leary's came on the scene, and they started preaching their gospel.
Free love and cheap drugs, so on and so forth.
Everybody had to try it.
People forgot how to handle the stress that came into their lives.
I don't remember in the 50s of things being stressful like this.

Leads right on into the recent times, such as up in Dallas several years ago, when suicides were the rule of the day of teenage kids in school, in high school, committing suicide because they couldn't take it anymore, couldn't take the pressure.
Really weird.
So that all started back in the early 60s, and it just, a door opened like a Pandora's box.
And once the flood started, it ripped out all the doorposts and reinforcements and it was wide open.
So it began to feed upon itself.
And the bigger it got, the more people jumped into it because it was so large they could be anonymous and still express themselves physically.
That's my understanding of it.
It may be way out in left field, but it helps me
forgive them if they have anything to be forgiven for.
And that takes the pressure off of me.
Because the whole thing was so enormous that no amount of avenging would ever wipe away its damage.
Only forgiveness would wipe it off.
It takes all the pressure off of me.
